diagram.mermaid:
flowchart TB
    %% AWS Architecture Diagram
    
    subgraph VPC["AWS VPC"]
        subgraph AZ1["Availability Zone A"]
            subgraph PublicSubnet1["Public Subnet"]
                AmazonAPIGateway["⚖️ API Gateway"]
            end
            subgraph PrivateSubnet1["Private Subnet"]
                AmazonLambda["⚡ Lambda"]
            end
        end
        subgraph DataLayer["Data Layer"]
            AmazonS3["📦 S3"]
            AmazonRDS["🗄️ RDS"]
        end
    end
    
    AmazonAPIGateway -->|Data Flow| AmazonLambda
    AmazonLambda -->|Data Flow| AmazonS3
    AmazonS3 -->|Data Flow| AmazonRDS
    
    classDef awsOrange fill:#FF9900,stroke:#E47911,stroke-width:2px,color:#232F3E
    classDef awsBlue fill:#3F48CC,stroke:#2E3A8C,stroke-width:2px,color:#fff
    classDef awsGreen fill:#569A31,stroke:#3F7B1C,stroke-width:2px,color:#fff
diagram.svg:
<svg width="850" height="550" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg">
      <defs>
        <style>
          .aws-title { font-family: 'Arial', sans-serif; font-size: 16px; font-weight: bold; fill: #232F3E; }
          .aws-service { cursor: pointer; }
          .aws-service:hover rect { opacity: 0.8; }
        </style>
        
        <!-- Arrow marker -->
        <marker id="arrowhead" markerWidth="8" markerHeight="6" refX="7" refY="3" orient="auto">
          <polygon points="0 0, 8 3, 0 6" fill="#232F3E"/>
        </marker>
        
        <!-- Service shadow -->
        <filter id="serviceShadow" x="-20%" y="-20%" width="140%" height="140%">
          <feDropShadow dx="1" dy="1" stdDeviation="1" flood-color="rgba(0,0,0,0.2)"/>
        </filter>
      </defs>
      
      <!-- Clean white background -->
      <rect width="100%" height="100%" fill="white"/>
      
      <!-- AWS Cloud header -->
      <rect x="0" y="0" width="850" height="40" fill="#232F3E"/>
      <text x="20" y="25" font-family="Arial, sans-serif" font-size="14" font-weight="bold" fill="white">AWS Cloud</text>
      
      <!-- Title -->
      <text x="425" y="70" text-anchor="middle" class="aws-title">
        AWS Architecture Diagram
      </text>
      
      <!-- Account boundaries -->
      
      <!-- Customer's AWS Account -->
      <rect x="80" y="120" width="500" height="380" fill="none" stroke="#232F3E" stroke-width="2" rx="8"/>
      <rect x="80" y="120" width="500" height="25" fill="#232F3E" rx="8"/>
      <text x="90" y="137" font-family="Arial, sans-serif" font-size="11" font-weight="bold" fill="white">Customer's AWS Account</text>
      
      <!-- AWS Managed Account -->
      <rect x="620" y="120" width="180" height="380" fill="none" stroke="#232F3E" stroke-width="2" rx="8"/>
      <rect x="620" y="120" width="180" height="25" fill="#232F3E" rx="8"/>
      <text x="630" y="137" font-family="Arial, sans-serif" font-size="11" font-weight="bold" fill="white">AWS Managed Account</text>
    
      
      <!-- User icon -->
      
      <g transform="translate(30, 450)">
        <circle cx="20" cy="20" r="16" fill="#666" stroke="white" stroke-width="2"/>
        <text x="20" y="25" text-anchor="middle" font-size="14" fill="white">👤</text>
        <text x="20" y="45" text-anchor="middle" font-family="Arial, sans-serif" font-size="9" fill="#666">User</text>
      </g>
    
      
      <!-- AWS Services -->
      
        <g class="aws-service" data-service="Amazon EC2">
          
        <g transform="translate(120, 160)">
          <!-- EC2 Instance Shape -->
          <rect x="10" y="15" width="80" height="40" rx="6" fill="#FF9900" 
                stroke="#E65100" stroke-width="2"/>
          <rect x="15" y="20" width="15" height="8" rx="2" fill="white" opacity="0.8"/>
          <rect x="35" y="20" width="15" height="8" rx="2" fill="white" opacity="0.8"/>
          <rect x="55" y="20" width="15" height="8" rx="2" fill="white" opacity="0.8"/>
          <rect x="75" y="20" width="10" height="8" rx="2" fill="white" opacity="0.8"/>
          <rect x="15" y="32" width="70" height="4" rx="1" fill="white" opacity="0.6"/>
          <rect x="15" y="38" width="70" height="4" rx="1" fill="white" opacity="0.6"/>
          <rect x="15" y="44" width="70" height="4" rx="1" fill="white" opacity="0.6"/>
          <text x="50" y="75" text-anchor="middle" font-family="Arial, sans-serif" 
                font-size="9" fill="#232F3E">EC2</text>
        </g>
      
        </g>
      
        <g class="aws-service" data-service="Amazon RDS">
          
        <g transform="translate(280, 160)">
          <!-- Database Cylinder Shape -->
          <ellipse cx="50" cy="15" rx="35" ry="10" fill="#3F48CC" stroke="#1976D2" stroke-width="2"/>
          <rect x="15" y="15" width="70" height="35" fill="#3F48CC" stroke="none"/>
          <ellipse cx="50" cy="50" rx="35" ry="10" fill="#3F48CC" stroke="#1976D2" stroke-width="2"/>
          <line x1="15" y1="15" x2="15" y2="50" stroke="#1976D2" stroke-width="2"/>
          <line x1="85" y1="15" x2="85" y2="50" stroke="#1976D2" stroke-width="2"/>
          <text x="50" y="35" text-anchor="middle" font-family="Arial, sans-serif" 
                font-size="10" font-weight="bold" fill="white">DB</text>
          <text x="50" y="75" text-anchor="middle" font-family="Arial, sans-serif" 
                font-size="9" fill="#232F3E">RDS</text>
        </g>
      
        </g>
      
        <g class="aws-service" data-service="Amazon S3">
          
        <g transform="translate(440, 160)">
          <!-- S3 Bucket Shape -->
          <path d="M10 20 Q10 10 20 10 L80 10 Q90 10 90 20 L90 50 Q90 60 80 60 L20 60 Q10 60 10 50 Z" 
                fill="#569A31" stroke="#2E7D32" stroke-width="2"/>
          <ellipse cx="50" cy="20" rx="40" ry="8" fill="#4CAF50" opacity="0.8"/>
          <ellipse cx="50" cy="25" rx="35" ry="6" fill="#66BB6A" opacity="0.6"/>
          <text x="50" y="45" text-anchor="middle" font-family="Arial, sans-serif" 
                font-size="10" font-weight="bold" fill="white">S3</text>
          <text x="50" y="75" text-anchor="middle" font-family="Arial, sans-serif" 
                font-size="9" fill="#232F3E">S3</text>
        </g>
      
        </g>
      
      
      <!-- Flow connections -->
      
          <line x1="170" y1="195" x2="330" y2="195" 
                stroke="#232F3E" stroke-width="2" marker-end="url(#arrowhead)"/>
        
          <line x1="330" y1="195" x2="490" y2="195" 
                stroke="#232F3E" stroke-width="2" marker-end="url(#arrowhead)"/>
        
      
      <!-- Step numbers -->
      
          <circle cx="250" cy="195" r="12" fill="#232F3E" stroke="white" stroke-width="2"/>
          <text x="250" y="199" text-anchor="middle" 
                font-family="Arial, sans-serif" font-size="10" font-weight="bold" fill="white">1</text>
        
          <circle cx="410" cy="195" r="12" fill="#232F3E" stroke="white" stroke-width="2"/>
          <text x="410" y="199" text-anchor="middle" 
                font-family="Arial, sans-serif" font-size="10" font-weight="bold" fill="white">2</text>
        
      
      <!-- AWS branding -->
      <text x="20" y="530" font-family="Arial, sans-serif" font-size="9" fill="#666">
        AWS Architecture • Generated by RFP Automation System
      </text>
    </svg>
diagram.description: Fallback architecture diagram with identified AWS services

connections.title: User/Client → Amazon EC2 (entry_point)
connections.description: Users or clients interact with the application hosted on Amazon EC2 instances.
technicalDetails: • The user/client communicates with the application using HTTPS protocol to ensure secure data transmission.
• The application is hosted on Amazon EC2 instances, which provide the compute resources to run the application code.
• The EC2 instances are configured with an Elastic Load Balancer (ELB) to distribute incoming traffic across multiple instances, ensuring high availability and scalability.
• The EC2 instances are part of an Auto Scaling group, which automatically scales the number of instances based on the incoming traffic and resource utilization.
securityConsiderations: • Implement strong authentication and authorization mechanisms, such as IAM roles and policies, to control access to the application.
• Enable HTTPS/TLS encryption for all client-server communication to protect sensitive data in transit.
• Configure security groups and network ACLs to control inbound and outbound traffic to the EC2 instances.
• Regularly review and update security patches and software versions on the EC2 instances.
performanceOptimizations: • Use Amazon CloudFront as a content delivery network (CDN) to cache static content and improve response times for users.
• Implement caching strategies, such as in-memory caching with Amazon ElastiCache, to reduce the load on the application servers.
• Continuously monitor the performance metrics of the EC2 instances, such as CPU utilization, memory usage, and network traffic, and scale the instances up or down accordingly.
• Leverage Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling to automatically adjust the number of instances based on the incoming traffic and resource utilization.
monitoringMetrics: • ELB request count and response times

connections.title: Amazon EC2 → Amazon RDS (database_access)
connections.description: The application hosted on Amazon EC2 instances accesses the database hosted on Amazon RDS.
technicalDetails: • The application running on the EC2 instances uses JDBC (Java Database Connectivity) to connect to the Amazon RDS database.
• The database connection is established using a secure SSL/TLS connection to protect the data in transit.
• The EC2 instances and the RDS database are placed in the same VPC (Virtual Private Cloud) to ensure secure and low-latency communication.
• The RDS database is configured with Multi-AZ deployment, which provides automatic failover to a standby replica in a different Availability Zone, ensuring high availability.
securityConsiderations: • Implement strong authentication and authorization mechanisms, such as IAM roles and policies, to control access to the RDS database.
• Enable encryption at rest for the RDS database to protect the data stored in the database.
• Configure security groups and network ACLs to control inbound and outbound traffic to the RDS database.
• Regularly review and update security patches and software versions on the RDS database.
performanceOptimizations: • Optimize the database schema and queries to improve the performance of the application.
• Implement caching strategies, such as query caching or result set caching, to reduce the load on the database.
• Leverage Amazon RDS read replicas to offload read-heavy workloads and improve the overall performance.
• Monitor the RDS database performance metrics, such as CPU utilization, memory usage, and network traffic, and scale the database instances accordingly.
monitoringMetrics: • RDS database connection count and latency

connections.title: Amazon EC2 → Amazon S3 (storage_access)
connections.description: The application hosted on Amazon EC2 instances accesses data stored in Amazon S3 buckets.
technicalDetails: • The application running on the EC2 instances uses the AWS SDK to interact with Amazon S3 and perform operations such as uploading, downloading, and managing objects.
• The communication between the EC2 instances and Amazon S3 is done over HTTPS to ensure secure data transfer.
• The S3 buckets are configured with appropriate access control policies to restrict access to authorized users and applications.
• The S3 buckets are configured with versioning and lifecycle policies to manage the retention and archiving of data.
securityConsiderations: • Implement strong authentication and authorization mechanisms, such as IAM roles and policies, to control access to the S3 buckets.
• Enable server-side encryption (SSE) for the S3 buckets to protect the data at rest.
• Configure S3 bucket policies and access control lists (ACLs) to control access to the objects stored in the buckets.
• Regularly review and update security policies and access controls to ensure the ongoing security of the S3 data.
performanceOptimizations: • Leverage Amazon S3 Transfer Acceleration to improve the upload and download performance of large files.
• Implement caching strategies, such as using Amazon CloudFront as a CDN, to cache frequently accessed objects and reduce the load on the S3 buckets.
• Optimize the data access patterns and object sizes to improve the overall performance of the S3 storage access.
• Monitor the S3 bucket performance metrics, such as request count, latency, and throughput, and scale the storage capacity accordingly.
monitoringMetrics: • S3 bucket request count and latency
• S3 bucket storage usage and capacity
• S3 bucket error rates and throttling events

summary.title: AWS Architecture Overview
summary.description: Executive summary of the fallback architecture analysis using Amazon EC2, Amazon RDS, and Amazon S3

keyComponents.purpose: Provides the compute capacity to run the application servers and handle user requests. Serves as the presentation and application tiers.
Manages the relational database that stores the application data. Serves as the data tier.
Provides object storage for static assets, logs, and other supporting data. Serves as a supporting service.

architecturePatterns: Three-tier architecture: The application is designed with a clear separation of concerns between the presentation, application, and data tiers, leveraging the strengths of each AWS service.
Stateless application design: The EC2 instances are designed to be stateless, with the database and object storage handling the persistent data storage.
Serverless supporting services: Amazon S3 is used as a serverless storage solution, offloading the management and scaling of the storage infrastructure.
scalabilityConsiderations: Horizontal scaling of EC2 instances: The application can scale out by adding more EC2 instances to handle increased user load.
Vertical scaling of EC2 instances: The EC2 instances can be scaled up by increasing the instance size (e.g., CPU, memory) to handle more compute-intensive workloads.
Scalable database with Amazon RDS: Amazon RDS provides automatic scaling capabilities, allowing the database to scale up or down based on the application's needs.
Scalable object storage with Amazon S3: Amazon S3 is a highly scalable object storage service that can handle increasing amounts of static assets and data without any manual intervention.
costOptimization: Leverage EC2 Auto Scaling: Implement Auto Scaling groups to automatically scale the EC2 instances up and down based on demand, ensuring efficient resource utilization and cost management.
Optimize database instance types: Carefully select the appropriate Amazon RDS instance types and configurations to match the application's performance requirements and optimize costs.
Utilize Amazon S3 storage classes: Leverage the different Amazon S3 storage classes (e.g., Standard, Infrequent Access, Glacier) to store data based on access patterns and cost requirements.
Implement cost monitoring and alerting: Set up cost monitoring and alerting mechanisms to track and manage the overall AWS spending, allowing for proactive cost optimization decisions.
